content: The Act may be cited as the "Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2008". The Attorney-Client Privilege Protection Act of 2008 emphasizes the importance of clarity and consistency in attorney-client privilege for effective compliance programs and internal investigations. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF ATTORNEY-CLIENT PRIVILEGE OR ADVANCEMENT OF COUNSEL FEES AS ELEMENTS OF COOPERATION. Sec. 3014 of Chapter 201 of title 18, United States Code, defines attorney-client privilege and attorney work product in the context of investigations and enforcement matters regarding organizations. The term 'organization' excludes continuing criminal enterprises, groups primarily seeking money through illegal acts, and terrorist organizations. In the Controlled Substances Act, any group seeking money through illegal acts or classified as a terrorist organization is excluded from attorney-client privilege and work product protections in federal investigations or enforcement matters.
